Situation1: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, phone pressed to my ear as the contractor rattled off another delay. The project was already behind schedule, and I could feel the pressure mounting from my firm to keep everything on track. Every minute counted, and I was expected to be available, to solve problems, to keep the team moving forward. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart tightened. My son’s bar mitzvah was only weeks away, and he still struggled with his Torah portion. I was supposed to be guiding him, teaching him the melodies, the meaning behind the words, passing on the traditions that shaped our family. My wife’s gentle reminders echoed in my mind—he needs you, this is important. Yet, the demands of the site, the endless calls, the looming deadlines, all pulled me away. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me, as I tried to balance the weight of my professional responsibilities with the sacred duty I owed my son. The phone buzzed again, and I stared at it, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more.
